Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The temple holds a routine evening chant.
Story: The laundry basket overflowed again, socks and shirts tumbling onto the hallway floor. My partner’s voice echoed from the kitchen, “Can you please fold the laundry tonight? I’ve got to finish this project.” I nodded, feeling the weight of the request settle on my shoulders. As a spouse, I wanted to share the load, to show I cared in these small, everyday ways. But tonight was also the temple’s evening chant—a ritual I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss, a time to reconnect with my sangha and my own practice. The clock ticked closer to seven. I could already hear the distant bell in my mind, calling the community together. My heart tugged in two directions: the warmth of home, the comfort of shared chores, and the quiet pull of the temple, the promise of peace and belonging. I stood in the hallway, laundry in my arms, torn between the expectations of love and the commitments of faith, unsure which path to take.
